entry.title: SAP PM. Issue in IW32 – Adding Components via Structure List, quantity field not default
entry.content:
(S4) When users attempt to add components to a work order in transaction IW32, they often use the reference object "Structure List" (likely accessed via IH01). However, in the screen where items can be selected, the "Quantity" field is not displayed by default—but e.g. the Unit of Measure (UoM) is visible.

As a result, each user must manually add once the Quantity field, which is inconvenient. According to SAP Support, this behavior is what it is, but it’s difficult to accept that such a "critical" field for this action cannot be set as default from start for all users.

Is there truly no way to configure this screen so that the Quantity field appears by default for everyone? It would significantly reduce onboarding effort and prevent the need to repeatedly instruct new users on how to add it manually.

entry.title: Generative AI, MCP and SAP; What are these and how to make the most of it?
entry.content:
Hi All,

Generative AI is the current buzzword in the market. Potentially, every clients, companies and adapting to it on fast pace. Recently SAP had introduced support for Model Context Protocol. With this particular blog, I'll be trying to make you all understand what MCP is, how we can make the best use of it for your SAP systems.

What is Model context protocol? (MCP)?
 It is basically an open, standardized approach that enables Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents to access up to date,  enterprise data - In our case, across SAP and other business systems on demand.

As Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT-4, Claude, Gemini, Llama3 etc evolve, we need standardized ways to connect them to tools, APIs, and systems. Imagine trying to follow different connectors/API for each LLM!
However, these models operate in isolation based on pre-trained data and don’t have built-in access to real-time data, databases , external APIs, or local files. Which is where MCP kicks in.

Below figure shows how MCP Client( Potentially LLMs or AI Agents) could connect to SAP systems.

MCP follows a client-server architecture, where:

  • Clients (like AI applications or LLMs) connect to
  • Servers (MCP tool providers) expose tools, APIs, or data sources to clients.

In our case, As an example- We can connect any AI agent to automate the workflows, or any AI models, using MCP to SAP systems, which would have access to the system and train from enterprise data.

Potential Use-cases:

  1. SAP GUI automation- Autonomous GUI Agent:

    Agent to automate interactions with SAP GUI, enabling programmatic control of SAP transactions. This can automate manual processes, activities which users perform on day to day basis.

    Automation scope:

    • Automation and workflows
    • Automating repetitive SAP business processes and transactions
    • Extracting specific data from SAP screens and tables for reporting or analysis
    • Integrating SAP GUI automation into AI-powered desktop assistants or custom applications

    How does it work?

    AI Agent can be fed with recorded steps, It can read and understand the fields, adapt with time; Unlike using RPA which is trained to exactly copy and execute the system actions.


    Advantage:
    Automate repetitive, heinous tasks.

  2. Enhanced Analytics and Reporting- Create dashboard and statistics.
    Scope:
    System reads, understands data and patterns and potentially (examples) answer below queries:

    “Whats the usage of product XXX?”
    “Tell me the product which is most used during XXX months/quarter?”

    Advantage:
    Build dashboards, reports instantly based on the data required

  3. Understand what custom functionality does, AI can read the code, Create of functional, technical documentations:

    Let’s consider a case where a vendor has done custom development and It is a blackbox to us, AI helps us to read, analyze and provide a basic understanding of the custom enhancement, saving time and efforts. The same can be extracted as documentation for future references.

    Examples:
    “Explain this legacy ABAP report in plain english and add detailed in-line comments”

    Result- Understand complex, undocumented Z-programs, making analysis and decisions faster.

  4.  Fiori MCP Server/Write UI5 code using agents:

    -Developers can build apps faster using MCP servers.
    -Write UI5 code using agents.

    Examples:
    “Add flexible row layout for the app”
    “Generate a new project and SAP Fiori app based on “my sketch.jpg”

    “How can I style an sap.m.Button to appear as a "reject" action?"
    "Help me migrate any deprecated UI5 API usage in this UI5 controller"

     

     

  5.  AI Assisted coding:

    MCP Clients to assist Consultants with coding, code reviews etc

  6. Smart IoT, Yard integrations, Smart Dock scheduling, Automated calls etc

    -Attain End to End track and trace information for Boxes with prompting

    -Dock Appointment scheduling using phone calls with AI voice assistant.

     

  7. Custom Chatbot- Only integrated for client data:

    End users can enquire, ask things to the chatbox which is integrated with SAP. (Can be Enabled for consultants as well).

    • Gain Information on business processes; In most organizations, Information relevant to any business process is often scattered across multiple business applications, databases, cloud systems, and files, both inside and outside of SAP. 
    • For AI agents to deliver meaningful answers and actions, they need access to all relevant data, not just data isolated SAP tables. 
    • With MCP, the connection between entire enterprise system and AI agents can be built easily.

     

  8.  How could this fit in EWM?

    Since I come from EWM (Extended Warehouse Management) background, These are few use-cases which I had in mind:
    • Custom Chatbot- only integrated for client data
    • Demand Forecasting- Enable models to predict future demand of products
    • Slotting & rearrangement- Suggest optimal bin placement for products- Helping drastically in production, Kanban processes, Urgent flows etc
    • Labour Management-Estimate, optimize workforce allocation.
    • Picking optimization- Learn, optimize picking routes for different processes on floor.
    • Learn queue, issues, patterns and take corrective/follow on actions.

     

    Please do share your feedback, ideas pertaining to your modules and your thoughts. Thanks for your time!

    Aman Orchard

entry.title: Automatic retry of Application Jobs in ABAP in Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

When moving from classic ABAP to ABAP in Cloud, one of the most common painpoints of the developers is the fact that they lose many familiar tools and options they had in the non-cloud systems. One of these tools are classical Batch Jobs, they have been replaced with Application Jobs in ABAP in Cloud, about this and some other issue @octavian_savu has a very good blog post where he explains some common challenges with Application Jobs in ABAP in Cloud.

In my case, we had multiple nightly Application Jobs that were occasionally failing due to network stability or downtime, and many of these failures were "fixable" with a simple retry, however without a 24/7 support we could not make sure that these jobs were retried when they failed. And this is a common fallacy of the "The Eight Fallacies of Distributed Computing", specifically "The network is reliable"

My plan was to build a robust retry framework for Application Jobs that will overcome these type of transient issues. I was very much inspired by the Phoenix bird who's rising from the ashes, so my goal was to make sure that the Application Jobs can rise from the ashes as well. The full source code of this framework can be found in here.

Problem Statement

In classical process chains(TCODE: RSPC), you are given the opportunity of configuring an automatic retry for a certain Job step in case of failure.

However in ABAP in Cloud you don't have such options unfortunately. So there's a gap in functionality that we'l need to address somehow. Why do we need to address it? 
That's simple, and I will give you an example for that:

Example

Let's assume you somehow decided to implement the MRP(or any other process, it doesn't matter) runs in Cloud, you have your development / support teams that sits in Berlin, the working day is from 07:00 - 15:00 UTC. And you also have 2 factories, one in Warsaw(work day 07:00 - 15:00 UTC) and one in Shanghai(work day 01:00 - 09:00 UTC).
At both factories you also have some production planners that need the data from the MRP run in order to be able to work, if the data is not there, their time is wasted. 
Let's say you have one MRP run per each factory and it takes 1 hour to complete, and you must run it not sooner than 2 hours before the factory opens, otherwise you will miss some important orders.
Therefore you will have the next schedule:

  • Warsaw MRP -> 05:00 - 06:00
  • Shanghai MRP -> 23:00 - 00:00

And let's assume a theoretical scenario when both of these Jobs have failed. The support team starts their work at ~07:00, this is when they restart the job, and at ~08:00 the job is completed. How much time did the production planners lose?

  • Warsaw - ~1-2 hours which is not that much, but still unpleasant
  • Shanghai - ~7-8 hours which is almost a full working day, completely unacceptable

Design goal

The ultimate goal is making sure that the system is able to "heal" itself and try again in case of failure. In order to translate this into ABAP code we will need a framework with the next requirements:

  • Automatically retries in case of failure
  • Has a configurable timeout between the retries to allow external systems to recover
  • Follows SOLID principles
  • Can be fitted into existing jobs with minimal refactoring
  • The class should be able to control the flow of the framework if needed.

In order to achieve this behavior I will introduce the Phoenix Framework. The idea behind of the phoenix framework is to introduce a thin architectural layer on top of the standard ABAP APJ(Application Jobs) runtime. The goal of this layer is to separate the technical orchestration of retires from the actual business logic of the Application Job, this way each job stays focused on what it needs to do, while the framework handles how it should react when something goes wrong. 

This behavior will be achieved by introducing a two-tier class structure, a pretty common OOP design. In general in most of the code we prefer composition over inheritance, but in this specific use case inheritance will be more suitable technique. 

  1. Base Class (zcl_phoenix_base) - Handles job lifecycle, and implements APJ contracts, plus it provides the retry engine. It will implement zif_phoenix and the encapsulated interfaces inside it.
  2. Child Class (f.ex. zcl_phoenix_job_mrp) - Inherits from zcl_phoenix_base, and will implement the business logic through hooks enforced by the interface.

besides that we will create a facade for this framework zif_phoenix, this interface will be serving multiple purposes:

  • Central point of keeping generic types specific for application jobs
  • Bundles multiple interfaces together
  • Defines an implementation contract for the child class.

Implementation

Interface

I will first provide the source code, and below will be the explanation

"! Phoenix framework interface
INTERFACE zif_phoenix PUBLIC.

  TYPES:
    BEGIN OF ty_job_params_range,
      sign   TYPE c LENGTH 1,
      option TYPE c LENGTH 2,
      low    TYPE c LENGTH 50,
      high   TYPE c LENGTH 50,
    END OF ty_job_params_range.

  TYPES: tt_job_params_range TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_job_params_range WITH EMPTY KEY.

  INTERFACES if_apj_dt_defaults.
  INTERFACES if_apj_rt_run.
  INTERFACES if_oo_adt_classrun.

  "! Run business logic <br>
  "! Implements the job-specific business logic. The framework invokes this
  "! once per attempt. If an exception derived from cx_root is raised, the
  "! framework logs it and may retry according to the configured retry settings.
  "! Keep this method idempotent or self-compensating so it remains safe under retries.
  "! @raising cx_root | Propagate any business error to signal failure to the framework.
  METHODS process RAISING cx_root.

  "! Set default attributes <br>
  "! Populate instance attributes that serve as defaults for scheduling and
  "! execution
  "! The base class calls this from if_apj_dt_defaults~fill_attribute_defaults
  "! so implementations do not depend on APJ types.
  METHODS fill_attribute_defaults.


  "! Get the delay before the next run <br/>
  "! @parameter retry_count | The retry count
  "! @parameter delay | How many seconds to wait before retrying the job
  METHODS get_next_delay IMPORTING retry_count TYPE i
                         RETURNING VALUE(delay) TYPE i.

ENDINTERFACE.

 So why do we implement the zif_phoenix interface? Simply it is just encapsulating the structure of our future Application Jobs.


The type ty_job_params_range is just made available in here for job parameters, as they will follow this shape if we want to be able to select multiple options, for more on this check SAP Docs.

And then we implement these 3 interfaces: if_apj_rt_run, if_apj_dt_defaults, if_oo_adt_classrun, but why do we need them? So let's take them one by one:
  • if_apj_rt_run - this is the default interface an application job should implement, without this interface a catalog cannot be created therefore we wouldn't be able to execute it as an application job, inside the if_apj_rt_run~main you should encapsulate your business logic. By having it inside  zif_phoenix we are basically saying that all the classes that implement zif_phoenix(or spoiler alert inherits from a class that implements it) will be "schedulable" as a batch job.
  • if_apj_dt_defaults - this is the interface where you define default values for the parameters passed ot the application job, you can either provide them in here, in the class constructor or as default values of the public attributes of the class.
  • if_oo_adt_classrun - a scheduled application job cannot be debugged, therefore we will introduce this interface for easier debugging of the business logic

Base Class Definition

CLASS zcl_phoenix_base DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  ABSTRACT
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES zif_phoenix.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="en">Retry Enabled</p>
    DATA retry_enabled TYPE zde_phoenix_retry_enabled VALUE 'X'.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="en">Number of retries</p>
    DATA retry_count TYPE zde_phoenix_retries VALUE 2.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="en">Cooldown time(s)</p>
    DATA sleep_value_s TYPE zde_phoenix_sleep VALUE 120.

  PROTECTED SECTION.
    DATA logger            TYPE REF TO zif_logger.

    "! Log informational message <br>
    "! Writes an informational entry to the application log (BALI) for the current attempt.
    "! Uses severity if_bali_constants=>c_severity_information.
    "! @parameter message | Text to persist in the application log.
    "! @raising   cx_bali_runtime | Thrown if the logger is not available or the log write fails.
    METHODS log_info
      IMPORTING !message TYPE cl_bali_free_text_setter=>ty_text
      RAISING   cx_bali_runtime.

    "! Log error message <br>
    "! Writes an error entry to the application log (BALI) for the current attempt.
    "! Uses severity if_bali_constants=>c_severity_error.
    "! @parameter message | Text to persist in the application log.
    "! @raising   cx_bali_runtime | Thrown if the logger is not available or the log write fails.
    METHODS log_error
      IMPORTING !message TYPE cl_bali_free_text_setter=>ty_text
      RAISING   cx_bali_runtime.

    "! Log warning message <br>
    "! Writes a warning entry to the application log (BALI) for the current attempt.
    "! Uses severity if_bali_constants=>c_severity_warning.
    "! Requires an initialized logger (created via create_logger( )).
    "! @parameter message | Text to persist in the application log.
    "! @raising   cx_bali_runtime | Thrown if the logger is not available or the log write fails.
    METHODS log_warning
      IMPORTING !message TYPE cl_bali_free_text_setter=>ty_text
      RAISING   cx_bali_runtime.

    "! Log success/status message <br>
    "! Writes a success entry to the application log (BALI) for the current attempt.
    "! Uses severity if_bali_constants=>c_severity_status.
    "! @parameter message | Text to persist in the application log.
    "! @raising   cx_bali_runtime | Thrown if the logger is not available or the log write fails.
    METHODS log_success
      IMPORTING !message TYPE cl_bali_free_text_setter=>ty_text
      RAISING   cx_bali_runtime.


  PRIVATE SECTION.
    CONSTANTS log_object_id            TYPE cl_bali_header_setter=>ty_object    VALUE 'ZLOG_PHOENIX'.
    CONSTANTS sublog_id_submission_job TYPE cl_bali_header_setter=>ty_subobject VALUE 'PHOENIX_LOG'.

    METHODS notify_about_failure.
    METHODS notify_teams.
    METHODS create_logger RAISING cx_bali_runtime
                                  cx_uuid_error.

ENDCLASS.

PUBLIC SECTION

We will of course implement the zif_phoenix interface that we defined before.
And we will also define 3 public attributes retry_enabled, retry_count, sleep_value_s.
These public attributes will be visible in the Job Scheduling screen so the person who schedules the job can control if he wants to have the retry functionality enabled, how many time the framework will retry the job, and how much time to wait between the retries.

PROTECTED SECTION

In here we define the PROTECTED area of the class, and if you don't remember what it is, it's the method / types that's not available to other classes but it's available to the children classes(that implement this base class)
As protected we have one global object called logger and I left it as protected on purpose, if any of the child classes would like to define some custom logging methods, they can access the logger object and define their own methods if the provided methods are not meeting the needs.

And we have 4 more logging methods that will log a message with a specific importance(info, success, warning, error), the consumer is encoruanegd to use these methods, and use the logger obejct itself only when these are not sufficient.

Using this logger and logging methods the consumer will be able to log to the Application Job Log that we see afterwards in the Fiori launchpad

PRIVATE SECTION

In the private section we defined some constants that we will use for logging into the application job log and also 2 methods for sending external notifications on a job failure, in our case we have a generic method that notifies about a failure, and this method just calls another method that will send a teams notification in case of failure.

Implementation

Now we have this base class, and the purpose of it, is that multiple child classes will implement this base class, and each child class will be a "schedulable" job, but we need a mechanism of how we can make this connection between the child class and base class, and how the child class will indicate to the base class what business logic to run.
We will do that via the same interface that we created: zif_phoenix, therefore we define 3 more methods

  • get_next_delay method will take as a parameter the retry_count and will return back the cooldown time the framework will need to wait before the next retry, this method will have a default implementation that simply returns the static input parameter of the job sleep_value_s, this method shall not be redefined by the child class unless they want some custom cooldown functionality like exponential backoff
  • fill_attribute_defaults method, this is just a wrapper for the if_apj_dt_defaults~fill_attribute_defaults method, and one could argue why do we need a wrapper why can't we just implement if_apj_dt_defaults~fill_attribute_defaults, we could, but we want to put an abstraction layer on top of it, and keep this concern into the base class, so the child class implements only the zif_phoenix and not any other interfaces like if_apj_dt_defaults
  • process method, probably the most important method, so the child class must redefine the process method, and implement it's business logic inside it, so assuming that you're refactoring a class that used before if_apj_rt_run, you'd rename if_apj_rt_run~main into zif_phoenix~process, the base class will afterwards call the process method again and again in case of retries

Therefore we already have a default implementation for some methods:

METHOD if_apj_dt_defaults~fill_attribute_defaults.
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  " STANDARD IMPLEMENTATION
  " MUST NOT BE REDEFINED, INSTEAD USE EXTENSION POINT:
  "   zif_phoenix~fill_attribute_defaults( ).
  "
  " This is just calling the wrapper class zif_phoenix~fill_attribute_defaults( ).
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  zif_phoenix~fill_attribute_defaults( ).
ENDMETHOD.

METHOD zif_phoenix~get_next_delay.
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  " STANDARD IMPLEMENTATION
  " CAN BE REDEFINED BY CHILD CLASS IF NEEDED(OPTIONAL)
  "
  " By default it will return the configured sleep_value_s
  " This is an extension point if the job needs a custom backoff f.ex. exponential backoff
  " the class could implement it something like this:
  "   RETURN sleep_value_s * ( 2 ** ( retry_count - 1 ) ).
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  RETURN sleep_value_s.
ENDMETHOD.

METHOD zif_phoenix~fill_attribute_defaults.
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  " CUSTOM BUSINESS IMPLEMENTATION
  " CAN BE REDEFINED BY CHILD CLASS IF NEEDED(OPTIONAL)
  " WRAPPER FUNCTION FOR if_apj_dt_defaults~fill_attribute_defaults
  " Q: Why do we need zif_phoenix~fill_attribute_defaults if the
  "    child class can implement if_apj_dt_defaults~fill_attribute_defaults
  " A: We don't want the child class to implement other interfaces other
  "    than zif_phoenix, this way we abstractize the child class from
  "    knowing the inside implementation of the framework
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
ENDMETHOD.


METHOD zif_phoenix~process.
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  " CUSTOM BUSINESS IMPLEMENTATION
  " MUST BE REDEFINED BY CHILD CLASS
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
ENDMETHOD.

I will skip over the implementation of the create_logger, log_info, log_error, log_success, log_warning, notify_about_failure, notify_teams methods because they're less relevant for this example.

Given that we'd like to run everything inside the if_apj_rt_run~execute when we are running the class inside ADT, this will be the implementation of the if_oo_adt_classrun~main:

METHOD if_oo_adt_classrun~main.
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  " STANDARD IMPLEMENTATION
  " NO NEED FOR REDEFENITION, BUT IT IS OKAY TO
  " if_oo_adt_classrun~main MUST NOT BE USED IN PRODUCTIVE SCENARIOS
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  TRY.
      if_apj_rt_run~execute( ).
      out->write( |Finished executing at { cl_abap_context_info=>get_system_time( ) }| ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO FINAL(exception).
      out->write( |Exception raised during execution: { exception->get_text( ) }| ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDMETHOD.

Now we got to the most interesting part, what do we put inside if_apj_rt_run~execute in order to retry the job on failure
We will start simple, first thing first, we'll try to calculate the total_attempts of the run that we can do, if the retry is disabled it will be 1, so it will run once, and won't retry, if it's enabled it will be the passed retry_count parameter + 1(the first run)

Next via a simple DO loop we will execute the zif_phoenix~process(which contains the job business logic inside), and if the execution is successful, we'll return, therefore we don't get to the next iteration of the DO loop, it will stop there and exit prematurely.

METHOD if_apj_rt_run~execute.
  FINAL(max_retries)    = COND i( WHEN retry_enabled = abap_true THEN retry_count ELSE 0 ).
  FINAL(total_attempts) = max_retries + 1.

  DO total_attempts TIMES.
    zif_phoenix~process( ).
    RETURN.
  ENDDO.
ENDMETHOD.

But will this be fault tolerant? No, as soon as zif_phoenix~process( ) raises an exception if_apj_rt_run~execute will be propagating the exception and prematurely terminate, so we don't get to the next DO iteration.

So we will just wrap it with a TRY CATCH block:

METHOD if_apj_rt_run~execute.
  FINAL(max_retries)    = COND i( WHEN retry_enabled = abap_true THEN retry_count ELSE 0 ).
  FINAL(total_attempts) = max_retries + 1.

  DO total_attempts TIMES.
    TRY.
        zif_phoenix~process( ).
        RETURN.
      CATCH cx_root INTO FINAL(ex).
    ENDTRY.
  ENDDO.
ENDMETHOD.

Congratulations, you have now a very simple fault tolerant application job framework, as soon as the zif_phoenix~process( ) raises an exception, the catch block catches it, and goes to the next iteration of the DO loop, as soon as the zif_phoenix~process( ) is successfull it will return so we don't run it too many times.

But we don't have any sleep functionality, so let's add it

METHOD if_apj_rt_run~execute.
  FINAL(max_retries)    = COND i( WHEN retry_enabled = abap_true THEN retry_count ELSE 0 ).
  FINAL(total_attempts) = max_retries + 1.

  DO total_attempts TIMES.
    TRY.
        zif_phoenix~process( ).
        RETURN.
      CATCH cx_root INTO FINAL(ex).
        IF sy-index <= max_retries.
          DATA(sleep_time_s) = zif_phoenix~get_next_delay( sy-index ).
          IF sleep_time_s > 0.
            WAIT UP TO sleep_time_s SECONDS.
          ENDIF.
          CONTINUE.
        ENDIF.
    ENDTRY.
  ENDDO.
ENDMETHOD.

Now on an exception we will get the next expected delay, will wait that amount of seconds and then continue with the next try.

But can you see the problem in this code?
The problem is that even if all the attempts of running the zif_phoenix~process are failing, the code will continue its normal flow after all failures, and will result in a succesfull job, which is false, so we'll raise an exception when we've exhausted all our attempts:

METHOD if_apj_rt_run~execute.
  FINAL(max_retries)    = COND i( WHEN retry_enabled = abap_true THEN retry_count ELSE 0 ).
  FINAL(total_attempts) = max_retries + 1.

  DO total_attempts TIMES.
    TRY.
        zif_phoenix~process( ).
        RETURN.
      CATCH cx_root INTO FINAL(ex).
        IF sy-index <= max_retries.
          DATA(sleep_time_s) = zif_phoenix~get_next_delay( sy-index ).
          IF sleep_time_s > 0.
            WAIT UP TO sleep_time_s SECONDS.
          ENDIF.
          CONTINUE.
        ENDIF.
        RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_apj_rt_content( previous = ex ).
    ENDTRY.
  ENDDO.
ENDMETHOD.

Now we'll add a bit of logging:

METHOD if_apj_rt_run~execute.
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  " STANDARD IMPLEMENTATION DO NOT REDEFINE
  " FOLLOW STANDARD FLOW
  " Enhancement Points:
  "   - process() must be redefined
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  TRY.
      FINAL(max_retries)    = COND i( WHEN retry_enabled = abap_true THEN retry_count ELSE 0 ).
      FINAL(total_attempts) = max_retries + 1.

      DO total_attempts TIMES.

        " new logger for each attempt, to have separation of logs in APJ
        create_logger( ).
        log_info( |Attempt { sy-index } of { total_attempts } started| ).

        TRY.
            zif_phoenix~process( ).
            log_success( |Processed successfully on attempt { sy-index }| ).
            RETURN.
          CATCH cx_root INTO FINAL(ex).
            IF sy-index <= max_retries.
              log_warning( |Attempt { sy-index } failed: { ex->get_text( ) }| ).
              notify_about_failure( ).
              DATA(sleep_time_s) = zif_phoenix~get_next_delay( sy-index ).
              IF sleep_time_s > 0.
                log_info( |Retrying in { sleep_value_s } seconds| ).
                WAIT UP TO sleep_time_s SECONDS.
              ENDIF.
              CONTINUE.
            ENDIF.

            log_error( |Exhausted { total_attempts } attempts: { ex->get_text( ) }| ).
            RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_apj_rt_content( previous = ex ).
        ENDTRY.

      ENDDO.

    CATCH cx_bali_runtime cx_uuid_error INTO FINAL(log_ex).
      RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_apj_rt_content( previous = log_ex ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDMETHOD.

Cool but what if the child class doesn't want to retry a specific exception, for example it knows for sure that this exception is not transient like some missing configuration, expired credentials, wrong data, etc?

In this case we will define a new exception class called zcx_phoenix_stop_retry and as soon as the child class raises this exception we don't retry, but just fail the job:

METHOD if_apj_rt_run~execute.
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  " STANDARD IMPLEMENTATION DO NOT REDEFINE
  " FOLLOW STANDARD FLOW
  " Enhancement Points:
  "   - process() must be redefined
  " ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  TRY.
      FINAL(max_retries)    = COND i( WHEN retry_enabled = abap_true THEN retry_count ELSE 0 ).
      FINAL(total_attempts) = max_retries + 1.

      DO total_attempts TIMES.

        " new logger for each attempt, to have separation of logs in APJ
        create_logger( ).
        log_info( |Attempt { sy-index } of { total_attempts } started| ).

        TRY.
            zif_phoenix~process( ).
            log_success( |Processed successfully on attempt { sy-index }| ).
            RETURN.
          CATCH zcx_phoenix_stop_retry INTO FINAL(stop_retry_ex).
            log_error( |The retrial was intentionally canceled: { stop_retry_ex->get_text( ) }| ).
            RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_apj_rt_content( previous = stop_retry_ex ).
          CATCH cx_root INTO FINAL(ex).
            IF sy-index <= max_retries.
              log_warning( |Attempt { sy-index } failed: { ex->get_text( ) }| ).
              notify_about_failure( ).
              DATA(sleep_time_s) = zif_phoenix~get_next_delay( sy-index ).
              IF sleep_time_s > 0.
                log_info( |Retrying in { sleep_value_s } seconds| ).
                WAIT UP TO sleep_time_s SECONDS.
              ENDIF.
              CONTINUE.
            ENDIF.

            log_error( |Exhausted { total_attempts } attempts: { ex->get_text( ) }| ).
            RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_apj_rt_content( previous = ex ).
        ENDTRY.

      ENDDO.

    CATCH cx_bali_runtime cx_uuid_error INTO FINAL(log_ex).
      RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_apj_rt_content( previous = log_ex ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDMETHOD.

If you'd like to see the full class implementation you can check out this link for the full source code.

So how to try it? Simply just inherit from the base class, so we will create a zcl_phoenix_demo:

CLASS zcl_phoenix_job_demo DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  INHERITING FROM /lego/cl_phoenix_base
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC .
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    METHODS /lego/if_phoenix~process REDEFINITION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
    DATA: x TYPE i value -1. "anti-pattern, not recommended
ENDCLASS.
CLASS zcl_phoenix_job_demo IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD /lego/if_phoenix~process.
    x = x + 1.
    DATA(a) = 1 / x.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

What does this class do? Simply it will fail on the first run, and will be successful on the second run, because it will no longer be dividing by 0, but by 1. However I must warn you that the global variables should be avoided in productive scenarios, I will explain why in the Limitations section.

We'll create a Job Catalog Entry and Job Template in order to schedule the job:

Now we can schedule it:

And this is the Job Result:

Improvement points

This code of course is not perfect, and there're various improvement points that could be done in order to make it better, however the goal of this blog post is not to showcase perfect code, but to explain conceptually how we can implement such a framework. Some of the improvements points could be:

  • make the code less nested by using checks and guard clauses
  • add a method to the facade interface to allow external classes to schedule the job(not executing, but scheduling in a different session) by calling that method
  • add a cleanup hook to run before each new trial

Limitations, considerations, gotchas, and side cases

And of course there're certain limitations to take into consideration and gotchas to avoid:

  • Biggest limitation is that you must design your classes to be stateless, because on a failure your class won't be reinstantiated instead the process method will run again, therefore you should try to avoid global variables as much as possible, because the state will be kept between runs
    It is of course fine to have global variables objects from dependency injection that were just instantiated in the constructor, this is perfectly fine. But you should avoid as much as possible having business data in global variables, as the stale data might introduce unnecessary side effects on the re-run.
  • Another gotcha is that there're certain uncatchable exceptions and the framework will unfortunately dump on these, because as the name suggests these are uncatchable and they will be propagated to a short dump, bypassing the try catch block.
  • One of the considerations is that you need to design your code in a manner where it will raise exceptions, instead of raising uncatchable exceptions, it might sound a bit confusing, but let me give you an example.
    So let's assume that you make an RFC call to an on-prem system this way:
"don't do this
call function 'some_rfc_fm'
  destination rfc_key
  exporting param       = 'value'
  importing return_data = return_data
  tables table_data     = table_data.

If the RFC call fails, it will raise an uncatchable exception and the program will dump, however we can modify it slightly in order to make it raise a catchable exception instead:

"do this instead
call function 'some_rfc_fm'
  destination rfc_key
  exporting param       = 'value'
  importing return_data = return_data
  tables table_data     = table_data.
  exceptions others = 1.

if sy-subrc <> 0.
  raise exception type cx_rfc_dest_provider_error "or any other exception that you want
  exporting textid = cx_rfc_dest_provider_error=>connection_failed.
endif.​

And a little caveat, it's not the best idea to put all the exception codes into 1 "bucket" with others = 1, and it's also probably not the best idea to raise just 1 type of exception, and specifically this type, but the goal of this example is to show how to convert an uncatchable exception into a catchable one.

Alternatives

Now at this stage an obvious question is are there any alternatives or flavors of this implementation? Yes there're, and I will explain some now:

  • Instead of retry on all except zcx_phoenix, retry only on zcx_phoenix. In case that you have a very good exception handling, and you're controlling each exception you're raising, you can refactor the framework so it will retry only on a specific custom exception, instead of retrying on all exceptions. This way you have a bit more granular control over your execution flow. Similarly how it's done in the bgPF framework.
RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_bgmc_operation( 
	retry_settings = VALUE #( 
		delay_time = 2
		do_retry   = abap_true ) ).​
  • Another flavor of a fault-tolerant job framework would include a bit of a paradigm change, and we will need to give up the base class - child class relationship with a single job architecture in favor of a driver - worker relationship. You will have a 2 job architecture, the 1st job will be the driver job, which will take as a parameter the name of the job with the business logic and it will schedule that job as the worker job, it will wait until that one has finished successfully, if it has failed then it will just spin up another worker job, until one finishes successfully. You should use this pattern in case the limitations listed in the limitations section are a showstopper for you, f.ex. you need a stateful job class with state isolation between runs. In my opinion this is a good approach but for certain usecases only, in general I prefer the current approach being more lightweight and flexible

Closing notes

The Phoenix Framework demonstrate that robust doesn't necessary mean complex, reliability can be achieved with a relatively simple and lightweight setup. With a structured retry mechanism we managed to achieve fault-tolerant jobs, and reduce manual recovery efforts.

This framework is not perfect, nor it should be, it's main goal is to ensure that people's time is respected and not wasted because of preventable issues.

Thanks for reading until here, and as a closing remark I must say that it's often through our failures that we find opportunities to improve, just like the Phoenix, this framework was born from the ashes of failed jobs, rising stronger each time.

If you're curious please check the full source code here.

entry.title: Re: Too many Data Records Selected for Monitor Material Coverage - Net and Individual Segments (App
entry.content:
Does anybody have the same error, when two or more exclude filters are used? For example in our case with a plant filter the app shows 50 records and no error. But if I want to exclude two specific materials of the 50 materials and add two filter values for material like !(=111111) and !(=222222) I got the same error "Too many Data Records Selected for Monitor Material Coverage" . But after excluding two materials, it should definetly be less than 50 in the result list. I assume that with the two exclude filters in the backend logic it exceeds at one point the 20000 limit even if the result is less. Do you recommend open a ticket for that or just increase the value of gc_max_materials?

It seems that, as soon as there are two exclude material filters defined, the it_filter table isn't filled correctly anymore in the method GET_HANA_SEL of class CL_MRP_BUFFER_SEL.

    " additional filter also in case of too many materials selected to reduce data records
    LOOP AT it_filter ASSIGNING <ls_filter>.
      CASE <ls_filter>-fieldname.
        WHEN cl_mrp_cockpit_metadata=>gc_mrptype.
          MOVE-CORRESPONDING <ls_filter>-selopt_t TO lt_mrptype.
        WHEN 'ISMARKEDFORDELETION'.
          MOVE-CORRESPONDING <ls_filter>-selopt_t TO lt_lvowk.
        WHEN cl_mrp_cockpit_metadata=>gc_mrpgroup.
          MOVE-CORRESPONDING <ls_filter>-selopt_t TO lt_mrpgroup.
      ENDCASE.
    ENDLOOP.

it_filter only has two filters and therefore the results exceeds the 20000 level, because the plant filter is missing.

With only one exclude filter, the it_filter table looks like this.

As for a quick fix, I will increase the gc_max_materials, but this will not fix the error permanently.

Thank you in advance for your considerations.

entry.title: SAP TechEd Virtual Business Data Cloud Session Recommendations
entry.content:
Every data team has that moment when the project road map looks clear—until the next critical business need arises. A new AI use case demands sub-second inference. A migration uncovers decades of business warehouse logic you can’t break. Forecasts need to turn into orders faster than the business can email another spreadsheet. When the stakes are this high, you don’t need more noise; you need the right signals to move from idea to impact. 

SAP TechEd Virtual is where you compress months of exploration into days of focused learning, with a front‑row seat to how SAP’s data and AI stack is evolving. Picture your team collaborating: your data engineer lines up an AI‑ready backbone, your data scientist charts a governed path from historical data to models, and your business analyst turns insights into coordinated action. To help you build that kind of high-impact agenda, here are a few sessions to look out for by role—each chosen to solve real problems you’re likely tackling or will tackle in the near future. 

For Data Engineers: 

  • SAP Business Data Cloud: Strategy, architecture, and vision (ST107v) 
    The SAP Business Data Cloud solution is a pivotal component of SAP's strategic initiatives. This solution facilitates the development and governance of data products, providing a robust foundation for analytics, artificial intelligence, and intelligent applications. It leverages contextual data and semantics to enhance the capabilities of these technologies. In this session, you will gain a better understanding of the architectural direction and data management priorities, ensuring a comprehensive approach to data management. 
  • SAP Business Data Cloud: The path forward for SAP Business Warehouse (DA203v) 
    Examine best practices for modernizing your SAP Business Warehouse (SAP BW) application utilizing the SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) solution. Gain insights into minimizing migration risks, preserving existing objects within SAP BW, and delivering these objects as managed data products and intelligent applications while leveraging the most recent data and AI capabilities in SAP BDC. 
  • What’s next for SAP HANA Cloud: Road map and innovation highlights (DA817v) 
    Gain insights into the future of SAP HANA Cloud in 2025 and beyond. Discover upcoming innovations for AI-driven application development, including the generative AI toolkit, tabular AI functions, and capabilities designed to facilitate data connectivity with AI agents. 
  • Accelerating your AI strategy with SAP HANA Cloud (DA201v) 
    Examine the embedded artificial intelligence capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud, which drive intelligent applications. Gain insights into the functionality of tabular AI, the SAP HANA Cloud vector engine, and the SAP HANA Cloud knowledge graph engine, which collectively support generative AI scenarios. These capabilities enable the development of context-rich, AI-driven applications on SAP Business Technology Platform. 

For Data Scientists: 

  • SAP HANA Cloud: The database for business AI (ST115v) 
    As the database foundation for SAP Business Technology Platform and the SAP Business Data Cloud solution, SAP HANA Cloud is pivotal to SAP's AI vision. Explore how SAP HANA Cloud facilitates advanced analytics, multi-model processing, and intelligent applications, particularly in the realms of machine learning and generative AI. Additionally, delve into the strategic roadmap for its future development. 
  • Build custom AI solutions with the generative AI hub (AI100v) 
    Gain expertise in developing AI applications tailored to your business needs by utilizing the generative AI hub functionality within AI Foundation. Explore the capabilities of crafting prompts and employing grounding, orchestration, and SDKs to create and deploy scalable, fact-based AI applications across various domains, including chat applications and retrieval augmented generation (RAG) systems. 
  • Power up and accelerate your business with SAP’s AI operating system (ST120v) 
    Prompt engineering has become a relic of the past. Embark on a journey into the future of SAP's AI operating system, your cornerstone for constructing, expanding, and executing AI at an unprecedented scale. Unveil the next frontier in LLM integration, automatic prompt optimization, grounding, and orchestration. Gain insights into how SAP's AI operating system propels secure and transformative AI outcomes. 
  • Building custom AI agents and skills with Joule Studio (AI105v) 
    Discover Joule Studio and the intricacies of extending Joule technology through custom skills and the creation of AI agents. Gain insights into the process of developing, deploying, and managing agents that align seamlessly with your business objectives. Benefit from live demonstrations and a comprehensive walkthrough of pivotal capabilities, catering specifically to developers and IT professionals. 
  • Empower your agents to be responsible (IN200v) 
    Gain an introduction to the evolving standards and protocols governing the interaction of AI agents with the APIs of applications, tools, resources, and large language models. Comprehend the pivotal role of the API Management capability within SAP Integration Suite in facilitating, regulating, and safeguarding these critical agentic integrations. 

For Business Analysts: 

  • SAP Business Data Cloud solution road map (DA806v) 
    Gain insights into the product roadmap for SAP Business Data Cloud and the ongoing development in key areas, such as data center availability, expanded support for data products and intelligent applications, new connectivity options, and other core enhancements. Discover SAP’s plans to continue delivering innovation to support your data strategy. 
  • Planning and analytics: Innovations powering SAP Business Data Cloud (DA207v) 
    Gain insights into how SAP Business Data Cloud facilitates unified, real-time planning and analytics, empowering businesses to collaborate, adapt, and achieve strategic objectives. Through illustrative examples and live demonstrations, explore how organizations modernize their planning processes, integrate AI insights, and unlock the comprehensive value of enterprise data. 
  • Transforming how people work with Joule technology (ST123v) 
    Gain insights into upcoming innovations, third-party integrations, and customization options from Joule that enable you to interact in innovative ways and access the information you require across your applications. Hear the latest announcements regarding Joule, uncover the driving forces behind its development, and understand how it is propelling the delivery of a groundbreaking user interface for the era of agentic AI.

You won’t want to miss these impactful sessions that will help you and your business simplify processes, deliver insights in fewer clicks, and create intuitive, human-centered experiences across applications. This virtual conference gives you a front-row view of what’s ahead in AI-driven application development, from generative tooling and tabular functions to data-to-agent capabilities that connect intelligence directly to your workflows.  

Browse the Virtual TechEd page and sign up today to secure your spot, then build your personalized schedule to lock in the sessions that matter most.

entry.title: 2H 2025- After enabling the shell bar users are unable to Run / Edit Story reports
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We've encountered an issue after enabling the Shell Bar in the 2H 2025 release where users are unable to Run or Edit Story Reports.

When attempting to interact with the reports, users are facing an unexpected behavior preventing access to the story report functionality.

 Details:

  • Release Affected: 2H 2025

  • Feature Involved: Shell Bar (Enabled)

  • Symptom: Inability to Run or Edit existing Story Reports.

Current Workaround:

The temporary workaround is to disable the Shell Bar. This restores the ability to run and edit Story Reports.

  1. company system and logo settings.

  2. Toggle off the Shell Bar feature.

  3. Clear browser cache and test the Story Reports again.

Has anyone else experienced this?

Please share if you have encountered this specific issue and if the workaround solved it for you, or if you've found an alternative solution. We're tracking this and hope for a fix soon.

Looking forward to your insights!

entry.title: New Enterprise Support Advisory Council Continuous Quality Check (CQC) Pilot for Customers
entry.content:
Greetings SAP Community! 

Big news! At the beginning in Q4 2025, SAP Enterprise Support will provide a new pilot Continuous Quality Check "Technical Preparation for SAP Signavio Process Insights and Intelligence " through the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC).

Quick Links

Scope

We recognize that turning process data into meaningful insights is essential to improving efficiency and supporting transformation initiatives. This engagement focuses on enabling a seamless connection between SAP Signavio Process Insights and SAP Signavio Process Intelligence through the Plug and Gain approach.

The Plug and Gain approach allows data from SAP Signavio Process Insights to be quickly and easily loaded into SAP Signavio Process Intelligence. This enables detailed analysis of process performance and execution, helping your organization accelerate transformation and continuous improvement efforts.

Typical use cases include:

  • Reducing complexity and cost in SAP S/4HANA transformation projects
  • Addressing challenges from mergers and acquisitions involving multiple system landscapes
  • Managing ERP environments with custom developments or outdated configurations
  • Avoiding the lengthy setup of traditional process mining projects

As part of this CQC, we will deliver:

  • A one-time data load from SAP Signavio Process Insights to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence.
  • A final report highlighting the insights gathered and the process walkthrough.

This CQC is designed to support the customer through the technical prerequisites and setup steps required to ensure a smooth onboarding process before using the Plug and Gain approach. We will support with the technical configuration, deployment of the value accelerators, and provide a final walkthrough of the selected process.

Prerequisites

To ensure a smooth onboarding process, it's important that you understand all the requirements to be met before you can use the plug and gain approach.:

  • Licences for: SAP Signavio Process Insights, SAP Signavio Enterprise Plus Edition, SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, SAP Signavio Process Manager, SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub.
  • You've connected at least one production SAP ERP system (SAP ECC 6.0 or SAP S/4HANA) to your SAP Signavio Process Insights tenant and at least one data collection has run.
  • You must have version ST-A/PI 01W SP0 or higher of the ST-A/PI plug-in installed in your SAP ERP source system. This version is required to ensure the content provided with plug and gain works as designed.
  • You've set up the SAP Signavio workspace that you intend to use, which includes SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, SAP Signavio Process Manager, and SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub.
  • You must have version ST-A/PI 01W SP0 or higher of the ST-A/PI plug-in installed in your SAP ERP source system. This version is required to ensure the content provided with plug and gain works as designed.
  • You've set up the SAP Signavio workspace that you intend to use, which includes SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, SAP Signavio Process Manager, and SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub.

Outcome

Upon completion of this CQC, you will have the necessary technical setup and understanding to use the Plug and Gain approach between SAP Signavio Process Insights and SAP Signavio Process Intelligence.

A final report will be provided, highlighting the insights gathered and the process walkthrough, enabling you to identify key opportunities for process improvement and future optimization.

Participation

  • This pilot is brought to you via the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC).
  • To find out more about the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council in general visit the website. 
  • To register you interest please contact us via email: esac@sap.com:

(Let us know your location / timezone, and state your interest in this pilot workstream.)

entry.title: SAP HANA System Replication (Active-Active) – XS Engine Accessibility & Application Routing
entry.content:
Hi SAP,

We are currently deploying SAP HANA system replication using the active-active (read-enabled) secondary replication feature.
As part of our architecture, applications access SAP HANA services—specifically the XS engine—via an HTTP load balancer.

Kindly help with below queries:

When using SAP HANA system replication in active-active (read-enabled) mode:

  1.  Is the XS engine service on the secondary node available and capable of accepting incoming connections during active-active replication, prior to any takeover?
  2. Can the HTTP load balancer route incoming application traffic (HTTP URL) to the secondary system’s XS engine under normal operation?
  3. Is it possible for users or administrators to access and log in to the XS engine on the secondary system using its direct server URL (bypassing load balancer), without takeover?
  4. Are there restrictions or known limitations which would prevent the secondary XS engine from accepting connections while active-active replication is configured?
  5. Please point us to a SAP note/document that contains the information asked in above queries.

Thanks.

Our PERSON_NAME version:

 

HDB version info:
  version:             2.00.079.PHONE_NUMBER
  branch:              fa/hana2sp07

entry.title: Re: SAP HANA System Replication (Active-Active) – XS Engi...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Thank you for contacting SAP Support.

As far as I know, the HTTP port of the xsengine is not opened on the secondary side in an Active/Active scenario.
The possible reason for this could be because the secondary is activated as read-only and the port is intentionally closed because the XSEngine does not differentiate between http-requests that really only read, and others that write.
So, I don't believe that the requirement you specified is possible to implement in the current HANA database revision. 

I've thoroughly searched SAP documents/Notes/KBAs today, but not been able to find the relevant information.
I believe this feature has not yet implemented, but also there is less possibility that it could be implemented in the future releases because of the reason above.

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: BRF+ (Business Rule Framework Plus) - Output Determination Process
entry.content:
BRF+  - Business Rule Framework Plus

Introduction:

  • BRF+ stands for Business Rule Framework plus which Provides a comprehensive application programming interface and user interface for defining business rules.
  • It enables you to define business rules without the need of writing ABAP Code.
  • BRF+ Function provides an interface between a business rule modelled with BRF+ and an application using that rule. The BRF+ function serves as a container for the entire business logic of a rule.
  • BRF+ is not new and even not directly related to SAP S/4HANA, but with the release of SAP S/4HANA 1610, BRF+ gained more attention since it is launched as the go-to solution for some business processes. The most important ones are the changes in Output Management for purchasing and Billing.
  • In order to use BRF+ with your SAP ECC system, your system must be on SAP NetWeaver 7.02 SP6 or above.
  • BRF+ supports features such as simulation, trace, transport, XML, export and import.
  • With SAP S/4 HANA a new Output Management Approach is in place. The complete configuration differs from the configuration that is used when Output Management is based on NAST (condition technique). The configuration is based on BRF+ in SAP S/4HANA is the target architecture is based on Adobe Document server and Adobe forms only. For the Form Determination Rules (along with other output parameters) BRF+ functionality is used.
  • Rules are Implemented as expressions which are assigned to the function. The rule input is known as “Context ”, and the rule output is called “Result”.
  • It is a part of SAP NetWeaver ABAP Stack.

Key Benefits:

All output parameters can be automatically determined via a configuration activity based on BRFplus. The benefits are:

  • You can send multiple messages to multiple recipients using multiple channels at the same time.
  • You can configure anything without the need for ABAP exits.
  • You can use each determination step on application-specific fields that can be extended.
  • You can use pre-delivered content/determination rules to simply run output control out of the box.
  • Extensibility via CDS is supported.

Important Note: Basis Team need to upload Standard XML Forms in SAP system. They import the forms by using BRF+ Transaction code.

If the forms aren't uploaded, we won't be able to see the Output Type in the OPD Transaction.

We can get the details of Form from SAP Note: 2248229 with the help of Basis download the note.

Here I am attaching the standard forms available in the SAP Note.

C:\Users\lingeswarak\Downloads\Standard XML formulas.xlsx

Limitations in BRF+:

  • Idoc s are not fully supported by the New Output Management. Their use is restricted to business applications that previously used NAST.
  • Only output types which can be mapped 1:1 to the NAST-KSCHL can use IDoc.
  • Only business partner-based communication is supported, but no communication to logical systems.
  • No ALE supports.
  • BRF+ doesn't fully integrate with the document management features provided by earlier SAP systems like SAP script or Smart Forms.
  • Compared to older output management solutions, error handling and debugging can be a bit more complex or less intuitive in BRF+.
  • It requires better integration of monitoring tools and workflows to identify issues with output processes, especially when compared to more established NAST error handling.

NAST to BRF+ Conversion Overview:

There are several updates and enhancements in SAP regarding the conversion from NAST to BRF+ for output management.

  1. Mandatory Use of BRF+ for Certain Documents:
  • With the release of SAP S/4HANA 1511, output management using BRF+ became mandatory for Purchase Orders. Similarly, in later versions, BRF+ is required for managing outputs of Sales Orders and Billing documents, replacing the traditional NAST-based output management.
  1. Increased Number of Supported XML Forms:
  • In earlier versions like SAP S/4HANA 1709, over 12 XML forms were supported. This number has significantly increased in subsequent versions, with SAP S/4HANA 1909 supporting over 20 XML forms. This expansion allows for a broader range of output types and formats to be managed using BRF+.
  1. Simplified Configuration and Integration:
  • The configuration process for BRF+ has been streamlined to reduce complexity. It allows for the easy import of XML files for output determination, simplifying the setup and customization of output types.
  1. Integration with SAP Fiori and Other UI Technologies:
  • BRF+ integrates seamlessly with SAP Fiori applications and other UI technologies like SAP GUI and SAP UI5. This integration ensures a consistent and modern user experience across different platforms.

In NAST, the configuration path that needs to be maintained is quite complex. The steps need to be followed are:

  1. Condition Table
  2. Access Sequence
  3. Condition Type
  4. Output Type
  5. Condition Record

For the BRF+ in S/4 HANA it is even simplified even business user can maintain Decision Table.

The steps need to follow are:

  1. Output Type
  2. Receiver
  3. Channel
  4. Printer Settings
  5. Email Settings
  6. Form Template

We maintain this configuration because it enables the use of SAP S/4HANA-based output management for Purchase Orders (POs), which is necessary for integrating with other systems like the Ariba Network and managing output messages efficiently in the SAP environment.

  • Even if you do not activate the specific step for SAP S/4HANA-Based Output Management related to integration with the Ariba Network, BRF+ (Business Rule Framework Plus) can still be used in SAP.

Configuration Path: SPRO→ IMG → Integration with Other SAP Components → Business Network Integration → Integration with the Ariba Network Application-specific settings → Define Message Output Control → Method 2: Use SAP S/4HANA-Based Output Management → Activate or Deactivate SAP S/4HANA-Based Output Management.

If you need to activate select the Mode: New output management is active and click on save.

Configuration steps:

  1. Storage repository settings
  2. Manage Application Object Type Activation
  3. Define Output Types
  4. Assign Output Channels
  5. Define Rules for Determination of Master Form Template
  6. Assign Form Templates
  7. Assign Email Templates
  8. Define Business Rules for Output Parameter Determination

Storage repository settings:

Configuration:  SPRO > Cross-Application Components > Document Management > General Data > Settings for Storage Systems > Maintain Storage System

SOMU_DB  is a standard content Repository for Output Management DB Storage.

If you can’t find the standard content Repository, click on the create tab and maintain the data mentioned below:

Content Repository: SOMU_DB  

Storage Type: SAP System

Version: 0047

If you want to customize, select the standard one and click on Copy as tab as shown change the content Repository name and click on save.

2. Manage Application Object Type Activation

Configuration: SPRO –> IMG –> Cross-Application Components -> Output Control -> Manage Application Object Type Activation

If you can’t see the standard Application object type in the screen, just click on Entries  and click on Help button and select the required Application object type as per the requirement and maintain status as active and click on save.

3. Define Output Types:

Configuration: SPRO –> IMG –> Cross-Application Components -> Output Control -> Define Output Types

The standard configuration is already set up. If the standard option is not visible, you can add it by clicking on "New Entries." To modify the output type, select the standard one, click "Copy As," assign the output type to the Application Object Type, and then save the changes.

4. Assign Output Channels:

Configuration: SPRO –> IMG –> Cross-Application Components –> Output Control –> Assign Output Channels

In this step we can assign output channels to application object type and output type.

5. Define Rules for Determination of Master Form Template

Configuration: : SPRO –> IMG –> Cross-Application Components –> Output Control –> Define Rules for Determination of Master Form Template

This step is used to establish rules that determine which master form template should be applied based on specific conditions or criteria.

In the "Define Rules for Determination of Master Form Template" step in BRF+, we maintain the rules and conditions that link specific criteria, such as document type, application area, or other relevant factors, to determine the appropriate master form template to be used.

6. Assign Form Templates:

Configuration: SPRO –> IMG –> Cross-Application Components –> Output Control –> Assign Form Templates

This step is used to link specific form templates to the rules or processes defined in BRF+. This step ensures that the correct form template is associated with a particular business scenario or document type based on the logic defined in the earlier steps, such as the "Define Rules for Determination of Master Form Template" step.

It enables the system to dynamically assign the appropriate form template for generating documents, reports, or outputs based on the conditions set in the rule framework.

After Maintaining the data click on save.

7. Assign Form Template:

 Configuration: SPRO –> IMG –> Cross-Application Components –> Output Control –> Assign Form Template

This step ensures that the correct form template is associated with a particular business scenario or document type based on the logic defined in the earlier steps, such as the "Define Rules for Determination of Master Form Template" step.

After Maintaining the data click on save.

8. Define Business Rules for Output Parameter Determination

Configuration: Configuration: SPRO –> IMG –> Cross-Application Components –> Output Control –> Define Business Rules for Output Parameter Determination

I won’t see the option for Purchase contract. So, I need to add template related to purchase contract in BRF+ Transaction code.

In settings select User Mode: Expert

In the Tools tab, choose the XML import, add the standard XML form for the Purchase contract, and include the transport requests.
The Customizing Request will store all the configuration settings for BRF+ that have been maintained.
The Workbench Request will store the configuration settings for Output Types.

Now, the Purchase Contract option is visible in the Output Parameter Determination.

For each step, click on Edit Tab and Maintain the appropriate data and click on Activate button.

The system will display a pop-up tab like want to activate the Output Type click on yes.

It will remain empty because the Email Recipient will be selected from the vendor master data maintained during vendor creation.

All the configuration settings have been done. Now create the contract in ME31K Transaction code with the Agreement Type “WK.”

The Agreement Number – 4600000002

Go the Change mode in ME32K enter the Agreement Number and click on Message Tab as shown.

The status will display as In Preparation to set the status to complete, select the line and click on the send Output tab as shown.

The status will change to “To be Output”

 After completion of this step come back and click on save the status will change to completed.

To check the print preview, click on the Display Document tab as shown.

entry.title: Re: Usage Record App new version

Hello Dhanashree,

Although the custom reference is part of the header it is built from multiple pairs as 'code: value'.   
Such 1:N columns are not exported. This is a restriction of the export control in SAPUI5, see https://ui5.sap.com/1.135.0/#/topic/4bab6f2043814257974b52d4dafe1dcd 

As long as this restriction exists the only way to export custom reference values is by using the public API here https://api.sap.com/api/UsageRecord_APIs/path/get_usage-records

entry.title: Re: Absence Counting Rules 2.0 in Time Management - 2H 2023
entry.content:
Hi @PriyankaAgarwal 

We are using this new method and it was working well till the new enhancement. After the recent enhancement separating the Requesting and Deduction fields for better clarity, we are facing an issue with non-account-based absences (specifically Maternity Leave). The enhancement causes user confusion as both fields now display with differing values.

Enhancement Background:

To enhance clarity when users take time off, SAP introduced an update separating the Requesting field into two clearer fields — Requesting and Deduction — highlighting both the user’s requested absence and its impact on the time account.

Issue Description:

We are using Absence Counting Configuration for Maternity Leave, which is Non-Account Based (no time account deduction involved).

 

  • Configuration:
    • System should deduct 0.5 days for each day of Maternity Leave
    • Maximum allowed: 61 days (i.e., 122 calendar days)

 

This setup was working correctly before the enhancement.

After the enhancement:

 

  • Both Requesting and Deduction fields are now displayed in the Employee Time screen.
  • When the user applies for Maternity Leave:

    • Requesting field shows 1 day
    • Deduction field shows 0.5 days

 

While the deduction logic is technically correct, end users are getting confused about which value represents the actual leave requested versus the counted leave.

Business Impact:

  • For Non-Account Based time types, showing both fields adds unnecessary confusion.
  • End users expect to see only one field representing the requested leave duration.
  • This impacts user experience and accuracy during leave application.

    Expected Behavior / Client Requirement:

    For Non-Account Based Absences (Time Types not dependent on Time Accounts):


    • Only the Requesting field should be displayed in the Employee Time screen.
    • The Deduction field should be hidden or not shown to the end user.

    This will ensure users view only one clear value when applying leave.

    Additional Analysis Performed:


    • Attempted to set both Requesting and Deduction fields to 0.5 days through Absence Counting Rules → only one field (Deduction) gets updated.
    • Tried updating Deduction Quantity and Deduction Factor → no impact.
    • The system behaviour consistently updates only the Deduction field for non-account based types.

Kindly provide your suggestion to make it to work as per existing.

Note: 

If we change it to “Work Schedule” or “Calendar Days”, the Absence Counting Configuration rule still executes in the background, but the 0.5 day deduction is not shown in the “Requesting” field — instead, it shows 1 day, which is not correct for our Maternity Leave requirement.

Our requirement is that when an employee applies for Maternity Leave, the system should display 0.5 day (as per the Absence Counting Configuration). Currently, this is possible only with “Deduction Quantity,” but that causes both “Requesting” and “Deduction” fields to appear, which confuses users.

 

Thanks,

Parthu.

entry.title: Effortlessly Sharing Themes Across Your SAP BTP Cloud Foundry Environments
entry.content:
Introduction 

The UI theme designer in SAP BTP offers the ability to export and import themes as ZIP files. While this provides a basic transport mechanism, it lacks the automation and convenience required for efficient theme management across multiple systems and landscapes.

SAP has introduced a new transport management feature that leverages the SAP Content Agent Service (CAS) and SAP Cloud Transport Management (CTM) to automate the transport of themes across SAP BTP Cloud Foundry environments.

 

How It Works 

The SAP Content Agent Service is a cloud-based application that is auto-entitled as part of the overall SAP BTP offering. BTP applications can register with the SAP Content Agent to expose their content, making it available for import, export and transport.

Users can now access the SAP Content Agent UI, select the desired theme artefacts from their SAP BTP subaccount, and bundle them into a transport unit. This transport bundle can then be seamlessly pushed to the SAP Cloud Transport Management system, which facilitates the distribution of the content across the target systems based on the configured transport landscape and routes.

The theming infrastructure in SAP BTP has been enhanced to integrate with the generic deployment and resource APIs provided by SAP. This integration allows theme artefacts to be registered as a new content type within the SAP Content Agent, enabling their inclusion in the centralised transport management approach.

For example, users can create or update themes in the UI theme designer and then access the SAP Content Agent UI to select the relevant theme artefacts. With a few clicks, the themes can be bundled into a transport package and sent to the SAP Cloud Transport Management system. The CTM then distributes the package to the target SAP BTP subaccounts according to the pre-configured transport routes and schedules. This ensures that the themes are automatically available and active in the target environments, ready for immediate consumption.

If you've already set up the SAP Content Agent Service (CAS), the “Theme" content type is readily available out-of-the-box in the export content wizard. This means you don't need to perform any additional configuration - the integration is already in place, allowing you to seamlessly select and transport your themes as part of the overall  transport process.
The setup of CAS is straightforward and well-explained in its documentation.
Visit the CTM SAP Help page to set up your transport landscape and find in the CAS documentation how to connect CAS with CTM. 

 

Conclusion 

The integration of theming capabilities with the SAP Content Agent and SAP Cloud Transport Management significantly simplifies the management of theme lifecycles across SAP BTP landscapes. This new approach provides a centralized, automated, and streamlined transport process, reducing the overhead associated with manual theme deployment and improving the overall efficiency of theme management.

Let's give it a try and leave your experience in the comment section.

entry.title: Re: Configuration: Group payment batches by bank in BCM,...
entry.content:
Good day @LuisaFernanda0204 

Thank you for your question.

The following references Payment Batch & Bank Communication Management provide more details.

To summarise, the ECC customising activity you mentioned is replaced in the public cloud edition by the configuration activity Define Payment Batch Grouping (SSCUI 103463) within Bank Communication Management.

You may access it through:

  • Central Business Configuration (CBC). First go to Finance à Bank Communication Management à Define Payment Batch Grouping.
  • Then assign your grouping rule in Assign Payment Batch Grouping Criteria (SSCUI 103464)

To group batches by bank, ensure you select House Bank as part of your grouping criteria. Optionally, you may also select Account ID.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAC Numeric Point - How to show last year same day value
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I'm working on a SAC story where I need to display the current day's sales and the sales from the same day in the previous year using numeric points.

However, I've run into a challenge. When I tried using the Previous Year function with a Restricted Measure, I encountered an error stating: "date dimension must be filtered on a single value on Month or a higher level," which prevented the previous year's data from displaying.

To work around this, I created a Calculated Measure using the formula:

LOOKUP([Sales], [d/Date] = Previous("Day", 365))

This works in most cases, but it has a flaw: it misaligns dates in leap years (e.g., February 29th vs. March 1st).

I've attached some screenshots. The first one is my story filter, the other two are the errors of the restricted measure I came across.

Does anyone know a more reliable method to display the previous year's same-day sales in a numeric point?

I'd appreciate any insights or better approaches!

SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: Merit Calculation Based on Different Current Salary
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We are working on a new compensation requirement that we hope someone has found a workaround for.

We want to use the standard Merit and Guidelines fields for the merit increase. Based on our investigation, the merit can be calculated either from the standard Current Salary field or from a custom field (ID = meritTarget). However, this custom field must be imported,  it cannot use formulas.

The main challenge is that the Current Salary field can only be mapped to a single pay component / pay component group. In our case, we have two different groups of employees:

  • Some employees have their current salary defined through one pay component group, and
  • Others have their current salary defined through a different pay component.

 We would like to continue using the standard Merit field and Guidelines for the merit increase.

We tried creating a custom field that would pull the appropriate pay component based on each employee’s setup and then use that field for the merit calculation. However, since custom fields can’t contain formulas, this approach doesn’t work.

One idea we are considering (but haven’t tested yet) is to use the Compounding Feature for this purpose. Our idea would be to:

  • Map the standard Current Salary field to the pay component group,
  • Map the standard Extra field to the pay component (this field would not be editable), and
  • Have the standard Merit field based on  the total of these two values (Current Salary + Extra).

However, we are aware that this isn’t the intended use of the Compounding Feature, so we’re not sure if it might cause unexpected behavior.

Has anyone tried a similar approach or found a more stable solution for this scenario? Any insights or best practices would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your help!
